narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the nature of climate change and pandemics in the context of global catastrophes and externalities. We discussed also in great length topics on innovation, uncertainty, human networks, culture and evolution.

I learned about the economics of climate change, as well as some of the science behind climate change. I also learned about some of the pitfalls/best ways to convince people to work towards mitigation. For the pandemics portion I learned about past pandemics, the current COVID-19 pandemic, and on a larger scale the way networks of people interact with each other. Overall very applicable knowledge!!

The key takeaway from this course was how multiple, seemingly unrelated disciplines can tie together based on fundamental concepts observed in the world. It was quite interesting to learn how climate change and pandemics can intersect, especially when varying the lense through which these topics are considered.

I learned how to build a simple Integrated Assessment Model; and about fat tail events, pandemics, collective action problems, and networks. I also learned to think more deeply about human existence and the institutions and culture that we create.
A good foundation in the economics of climate change and the sociology of pandemics.

I certainly have a better view of two of the main issues facing our world today, those being climate change and pandemics. I understand their history, their future, and the ways we should analyze and study them. I was able to think quantitatively, theoretically, analytically, and abstractly in this course.
I developed critical thinking skills in the context of climate change and pandemics. I also gained an understanding of how the two are more related than people may realize.
An array of insights surrounding climate change and pandemics.

I learned how to make climate change/economics models through my problem sets  I found this exercise really engaging and insightful because I got the chance to see how policy and economics influence one another. I also learned a lot about network science and how our social connections can shape the way we interact and  how catastrophes like pandemics can play out.

This course covered a wide variety of material ranging from basic economic concepts to an introduction to epidemiology and the history of pandemics in human society. I learned to read scientific papers on the topic, and the class taught material the lies at the intersection of economics, anthropology, and sociology.

A huge range of topics in climate change and pandemics, including the general idea of fat tailed events and how we as a society can handle these issues. A partial list: carbon pricing, integrated climate assessment models, vaccination strategies, social network science and how this affects vaccination, human cooperation and game theory, the idea of cliodynamics, the relationship between human evolution and culture, and more...
I learned about the economics of climate change and uncertainty as well as a sociological perspective on pandemics and cooperation.
Overview of IAM model and social network theories.

The course was divided into 4 parts, 2 devoted to pandemics (covered COVID-19 virus properties, network dynamics/social networks and how they affect viral spread/interventions, social behavior/dynamics, etc.) and 2 devoted to climate change (IAMs, climate science, externalities, fat tails, cooperation, etc.). Overall, the idea of the course is to examine global catastrophes from a technical perspective (e.g., properties of COVID-19, climate science) as well as a social perspective (collective action/cooperation, decision making under uncertainty, how social network structure affects decisions, etc.)
Developing models; knowledge on covid.
I learned more about COVID-19 and climate change.

I learned the fundamental concepts and components of integrated assesment models in order to optimize policy choices to mitigate carbon pollution. In the other portion of the class, I learned a very interesting spread of sociology concepts about networks helpful for understanding the spread of not only diseases (very fitting given the pandemic), but also information and ideas.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Having two star professors teach such a course was a real privilege. I was hanging from every single thing that Professor Christakis was saying. He was by far the most engaging lecturer I have ever had at Yale. Professor Nordhaus was also really good but certainly did not have the same command of speech as Professor Christakis. Still the conversations and engagements I had with both will remain with me well after my Yale years are over. The course is worth it only to get to meet these two amazing people. I feel like I have learned genuinely interesting information that is going to be useful in my understanding of global current events. 

Weaknesses: Even though the lectures were great, I cannot say the same for the 3 psets we had. They were really disorganized and I felt very lost every time I began solving one. For the next iteration of the course Professor Nordhaus should try to give students more guidance on the things they have to do and also try to make the math more straightforward. I felt like they were unnecessarily complicated and difficult. I had to exchange so many emails with the TA every single time only to get a basic understanding of what we were supposed to do. It should not be this way. 

On the other hand, the weakness from the part of Professors Christakis were the lecture slides. Even though he is an amazing speaker, his slides were very rudimentary and missed most of the things he discussed. This meant that we had to go back during exams and re-listen to the lectures in order to study. If this course is offered again he should make an effort to have more complete slides.

Strengths: the subject matter of the class is sooo interesting and applicable right now. Nordhaus and Christakis are clearly very knowledgeable about their respective topics, and it was eye-opening to hear a bit from such experts! Section was also great, Simon cleared up some topics and made a lot of connections between the two. Overall the quizzes and psets were fair.

Weaknesses: Christakis was not very compassionate towards the needs of the students. We had an assessment scheduled the day after a break day, and two days after the death of Rachel, and it was not moved. He did not even address the loss experienced by the Yale community in class at all. It was very difficult for me, and I can imagine for other students, to have space to mourn but also have to focus on studying for an assessment immediately after, not to mention it was already not supposed to be held the day after a break day!
At first, there was too much lecture and little time allocated to questions. This did change as the course progressed.

Strengths: the small class size was the best part of this course. I hope that in future years, both professors can offer this class with a similar class size. It was a great gift to be able to ask questions and get to know classmates on Zoom, and if class sizes were larger, the course would not be as good. 

Both professors are also incredible. See more comments below.

Weaknesses: The readings in Prof. Christakis' section were packed too tightly in some places. For example, we would have to read 150-200 pages for a week, but only 15 pages for other weeks. Perhaps it could be possible to better distribute the reading load across lessons. It might also be useful to have TA sections that focused on the pandemic material. Simon was absolutely fantastic and did his best, but in future years, it might be helpful to have dedicated sections for the pandemics material.

The instructors are both very knowledgeable and clearly passionate about the course, which made lectures interesting. I do wish there were more practice problems given so that we could prepare for exams.

The strengths are certainly the professors, a Nobel prize winning economist and a world-renowned epidemiologist. If anything, take the course to say you took a course with the two of them. That being said, this was the first iteration of this course. I did not like the quizzes. The questions were often vague. Even if you studied the material from class, you weren't guaranteed a great grade on the quiz because of this. The grading by the TA should have been a bit more lenient given the vagueness and time constraints on the quiz. That being said, the readings in the class were interesting and listening to the professors' thoughts was great. The class sessions were very long and being on Zoom definitely was not helpful when it comes to maintaining focus during class.

The course is organized into alternating sections between the two professors, which leads to the aggregate sum of the course material being a quilt of fairly disconnected concepts. The continuity between topics isnt emphasized and the class feels like two survey courses at once.
The material covered in lecture was interesting and engaging. Some of the readings, however, were a bit technical.
Interesting class but pretty disorganized.

I really liked the lecture-seminar style of the course. I appreciated how we had the opportunity to ask questions in class as we were learning the material; being able to hear what my classmates had to say definitely enhanced the learning process. I think the professors also did a great job trying to unify the course with some cross-cutting topics, but I do wish we went more in-depth with this.

I wish we did more in class simulations  maybe with DICE models and more on Breadboard  I feel like those activities would be engaging and help students remember the content more.

The strength of the course is the legendary instructors. Nordhaus and Cristakis are among the most respected members of their respective fields, so it was an honor to be able to listen to them and pose questions to them. However, given that this was the first time the course was offered, it was rather unstructured. The material didnt feel all that cohesive across the climate change and pandemic sides of the course. Although I feel like I learned a good amount of information, it felt rather scattered. I would not say there is a cohesive narrative that links all the aspects of the course together.

Professor Nordhaus and Professor Christakis were extremely knowledgeable, not just about their particular areas of focus but how everything fit into the big picture.

The only potential weakness is that it's a high-level overview rather than a specific / technical course, so you won't for example be going over the details of the DICE model in depth. The material is provided if you're interested, though, and I think knowing that these topics exist and how they fit into the bigger picture is enough to do your own investigation!

I thought that the content of this course was fascinating and timely. I had never really considered climate change from an economic perspective, nor taken any kind of medical or sociological course before, and loved to hear about them from true experts. While the problem sets could have benefitted from a bit more guidance and took a very long time, I felt that they reinforced class content well. I think that the sociology part of the course should have had some low-stakes assignments, too, however, in order to balance out the workload. Also, the readings ranged from wonderfully relevant to I-don't-understand-remotely-why-we-were-assigned-this. Quizzes and the final were very fair questions (though, I wish we were given more specific feedback in grading). Given that this was the first iteration of the class, this turned out to be a very strong course!
Strengths are the professors, no doubt. I don't think there's another opportunity to have two such phenomenal professors co-teaching a class that is so relevant to the status quo.

Both professors are experts in their fields and had special insights into the topics that you don't get from other courses. For example, many of the topics were based on their published research. The structure of the class in terms of problem sets ever so often and 1 quiz per part of the course were good at keeping us accountable to the material. Professor Nordhaus and Christakis have pretty different lecturing styles, which can be a bit jarring when switching from one part of the course to another (I think this might improve because this was the first year the course was taught). Also, I wish that Professor Christakis's two parts of the course were more related to each other. I think the second part of the Pandemics portion could have referred back to pandemics a bit more (it did, and I know why that material was important, but the material could relate to both climate change and pandemics and it wasn't presented that way in the syllabus).
I like that the course covers a lot of ground. I don't like that the lecturers tried to include so many readings but only used them minimally in the course.

The strengths were the quality of lectures. Professor Nordhaus' lectures were always very informative despite being fairly casual, and professor Christakis' lectures were always very-well spoken and engaging. The concepts in this course made focusing very easy since the topics are very relevant. It is hard not to be engaged in lectures about climate change and pandemics when half of CA is on fire and Covid is still keeping students from attending classes in-person. This was a pilot-course so the professors' casual attitudes and willingness to have conversations with students during, after, and outside of class made the atmosphere very welcoming and motivating. I hope this quality continues. Also, having the other professor sit-in during lectures from the other was always fun because they would hop-in and ask interesting questions or offer insights from their own respective field. Another great upside was the quality of our TF, Simon. At the end of every week he always gave a concise breakdown of what we had been learning througout the week and always added in interesting concepts from papers he had found in his own free time that were relevant. A downside would be that being a pilot course, the assignment structures could be a bit more polished. The econ-half of the course had psets due every couple of weeks that were primarily in microsoft excel and given with arguably ambiguous instructions while the sociology-half of the course had no psets at all. Also, at the end of every 4-ish week-long set of lectures from one professor, there would be a quiz at the end of class that we were not given much information about to help us prepare. The feedback given by the TF's during section or on the quiz results were always helpful, though.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Honestly, this was one of the zoom lectures that I enjoyed more than others. Both professors were very engaging and made it easy to stay focused! Another thing that really helped with the zoom format is that Nordhaus in particular would often give us 2-3 minute breaks during the lecture, this made a HUGE difference in my concentration during the later half. 

There were also a few classes where we played a network "game" designed by Christakis's lab that was very interesting and helpful in varying the classes, but also in seeing what we were learning play out in action!
It was a great gift to have a small class size, with lectures with lots of discussion at the end.

I would hope the class would be more interactive in the future. Perhaps when it is taught in person, there are more turns for people to participate. And this was not a problem caused by the professors but more so the general pandemic-style of learning. In fact, the professors were yearning for more participation but Zoom does not help with student participation.

The grading scheme is designed to decrease stress but it induces more pressure. Each quiz is 20 minutes long with four questions - yet the four of these quizzes count for 10% of our grade each. Moreover, during the course there was a poll that was offered on the length of the exams and the professor reported that 70% of students wanted longer quizzes. Ironically, the poll used for an example on the difference between supermajority and majority votes in international agreements. The teachers did not bother to address this concern for the final quiz. 

The grading for each quiz differed between professors and at times was extremely opaque as several questions required lengthy answers for full points. The allotted time for quizzes is too short for such answers.
The lecture-seminar structure was great! I also liked the online simulations that we did  I appreciated learning in action.
Live lectures were engaging and students could contribute since that class size was relatively small.

The social games using Breadboard were really interesting and engaging, and were actually more effective than would be in-person!

It was sometimes a bit hard to get a fluid discussion, the way that you would have with no latency in-person. I think we made a lot of the situation but it's just not exactly the same.
I really liked the in-class simulations in the sociology units -- I felt that they took advantage of the Zoom medium well.
Zoom lectures worked well but were not as conducive to discussion.
The live virtual lectures are good.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, definitely. Do yourself a favor and take this course. You do not need to have a background in any of the two fields. Even though it had a few rough edges, this was to be expected as it was the very first time that it was offered. I expect it to improve as a course from here onwards.
Yes. It was not a ton of work, but I learned a lot anyways and I will bring the knowledge I got in this class in to many of my future classes because it is so interdisciplinary and applicable!
Yes. This course gracefully combines multiple disciplines into a cohesive, semester-long course. taught by two absolute experts in the key topics covered.

Yes, without reservation. This course may have been the most enjoyable class that I have ever taken at Yale, and certainly one of the best online classes I have ever taken. The class was small--20 or 30 students in total--and was oriented toward discussion. The opportunity and access to talk with Prof. Christakis and Prof. Nordhaus was incredible. 

Both professors are incredibly knowledgeable, kind, and humorous. They are each such great scholars of their own field, but they also are incredible scholars of the world at large. 

The course material is so important to be an informed citizen in the world, and it was delivered with such great enthusiasm and care. The amount of homework in this class is low, and the quizzes during the semester are low-stress and much preferable to a midterm.
I would recommend it to a student interested in the two main topics- climate change and pandemics. I would also recommend it to learn from Professor Nordhaus and Professor Christakis.

Depends. It is a survey course split between two different professors. If a student is interested in learning a little bit about only two types of catastrophes themselves (climate change and pandemics) - maybe. The student invested in climate change economics will not be as interested in the pandemics portion of the class and even the discussion on the social suite.
This course is suitable for anyone interested in climate change, public health, or catastrophes in general. These topics are ones that everyone should have an appreciation for.

Yes! This is a great course to see economics applied to climate change (two topics not very many people would associate with each other) and the basics of network science and how that relates to pandemics. I appreciated the narrowed focus and structure of the course because it definitely helped facilitate conversation and overall engagement.

I think this course offers a great opportunity to learn up close from some of the greatest minds Yale has to offer. Nevertheless, it is hard for me to recommend the course because the course was simply too unstructured. It felt haphazardly put together, and my level of engagement often felt low.
Yes, the topics were really interesting and relevant. The ideas that you learn are applicable to a wide range of human social issues beyond just climate change or pandemics.
Yes! This course was fun and very interesting. I am confident that the professors will iron out the slight negatives from this semester and you'll have a great time!
Yes. You will learn much more than the course material itself.

Yes! This course introduces several aspects of COVID-19 and climate change from different fields, and so people from multiple backgrounds will be able to take this course and take away something that relates to their field of interest. I took this course in my last semester at Yale after taking a variety of courses from other fields and it made it easier for me to take in and appreciate the interdisciplinary nature of the course, so I'd also recommend it as an elective for juniors/seniors.
Yes. It covered diversified topics.
Yes, because everything taught in this course is very relevant especially today.
